results.title: The Blowfly menace
results.creator_credit: A. C. McKay BVSc and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: For farmers and graziers this study of the life-cycle of the green blowfly and other flies associated with blowfly strike in sheep, and demonstrations of various methods of control, should prove both useful and interesting.

results.title: Before production begins
results.brief_description: The story of the birth of a new Holden car, from an artist’s conception, through the modelling of small and full scale models, to the making of the first prototype model. From the hundreds of scale drawings, skilled craftsmen create by hand, the hundreds of engine and body components of the prototype. Laboratory and road tests of components and the completed prototype ensue that every section of the car conforms to rigid engineering specifications. Only after all this preliminary work can mass production begin on a new model Holden car.

results.title: [The Australian outback]
results.brief_description: On a cattle station 200 miles from Oodnadatta, stockmen are shown preparing for a muster, mustering scrub cattle, branding and droving the cattle to the trucking yards.

results.title: Coma
results.creator_credit: Ray Argall, St John Ambulance Australia and British Petroleum
results.brief_description:
Coma can be caused by epilspsy, drowning, drug overdose or head injuries. Shows what to do for people in a deep coma. The victim should be moved into the approved coma position until medical help arrives. It is the only treatment that a first aider can and should apply.

PLEASE NOTE: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date first-aid practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Bushfire: our summer fate
results.brief_description: Shows how a bushfire in the Blue Mountains on 6 December 1977 caused the death of one person, 70 homes to be destroyed and the evacuation of thousands all in a space of five hours and similarly how the bushfire of summer 1967 in Hobart killed 62 people and destroyed upto 1000 homes and 130 major buildings. Includes a report by scientist David Ellyards on how, where and why bushfires start in Australia followed up by how to prevent death and destruction due to bushfires.

results.title: On time
results.creator_credit: Victorian Railways, Eric Thompson and Department of the Interior
results.brief_description: More than 100,000 train passengers pass through the gates at Flinders Street Station, Melbourne each day. Control of passenger and freight trains in and out of the station on time is a masterpiece of precision planning.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian Railways, Eric Thompson and Department of the Interior

results.title: Making glass for houses
results.brief_description: Sand, limestone, and soda ash are the raw materials of glass; this film shows how they are obtained, and how they are manufactured into glass, both in the laboratory, and in a modern industrial plant, and the many uses of glass in houses.

results.title: Natural Glass
results.creator_credit: John King, Derek Wright and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Looks at a one-man revival of “natural” glass-making in New Zealand, contrasting the delicacies of glass making by one man with his normal job as a worker in a natural gas field.

results.title: [Cinesound Review: Royal Tour Concludes]
results.creator_credit: Peter Bell, William M. Carty and Cinesound
results.brief_description:
This film is a Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The newsreel shows the final leg of the 1970 Royal Tour with Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne, for the bicentenary celebrations of the arrival of Captain James Cook in Australia in 1770.

The film shows the royal family arriving in Brisbane, Queensland, on the Royal Yacht Britannia, where they are greeted by crowds of people in hundreds of boats on the river. It shows the family attending various events, including a welcome at Parliament House, theatre shows and a children’s parade at Lang Park, or Brisbane Stadium.

Princess Anne visits a sheep station at Cunnamulla, Queensland, while Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip visit the mines at Mount Isa, Queensland.

The film shows bicentenary celebrations in Cooktown, Queensland, and Botany Bay, New South Wales. These celebrations include a speech by the Queen and re-enactments of Captain James Cook’s arrival in Australia in 1770, with interactions with Aboriginal Australian people.

The film continues with fireworks over Sydney Harbour; an ANZAC Day march in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory; Prince Philip playing polo with a local team; and the opening of the international terminal at Sydney Airport, from which the royal family departs.
